wikipedia_page.main: Christopher Norman "Chris" Pyne (14 February 1939, Bridlington, East Riding of Yorkshire, England – 12 April 1995, London) was an English jazz trombonist.

response: * The Source – From and Towards (1971, Tangent Records) (recorded 18 November 1970; featuring Trevor Watts, Ray Warleigh, Brian Smith, Ken (sic) Wheeler, Bob Norden, Chris Pyne, Mick Pyne, Ron Mathewson, Marcio Mattos, John Stevens)

| 1971 || octet w/ Norma Winstone, Stan Sulzmann, John Surman, Kenny Wheeler, Chris Pyne, Chris Laurence, Tony Levin || Pause, and Think Again || Turtle || produced by John Surman; re-released 1995 on FMR

Between late 1967 and 1972 Jones lived in London and Paris,"About Philly Joe Jones", MTV Artists. performing and recording with musicians including Archie Shepp, Mal Waldron and Hank Mobley."Philly Joe Jones Discography - session index", Jazzdisco.org. For two years (1967–69) Jones taught at a specially organized school in Hampstead, London, but was prevented from otherwise working in the UK by the Musicians' Union. His 1968 album Mo' Joe (also released as Trailways Express)"Philly Joe Jones – Trailways Express (aka Mo' Joe)", Dusty Groove. was recorded in London with local musicians (including Peter King, Harold McNair, Chris Pyne, Kenny Wheeler and others)."Philly Joe Jones: Mo' Joe – Credits", AllMusic.
* Andy Fawbert, Peter Thoms, Chris Pyne, Alan Hutt – trombone

response: In 1968 Wells began a PhD course in philosophy at London University, living in a house that was also home to bass player Ron Mathewson, alto sax player Ray Warleigh, trombonist Chris Pyne and pianist Mick Pyne. Mathewson was then playing in the quartet of tenor player Tubby Hayes, and asked Wells if he would be interested in joining the group. He arranged an audition with Hayes and guitarist Louis Stewart, at which "We played a blues, and Tubby looked at Ron and Louis and then said, 'Do you want the job?' Want the job. With the greatest jazz quartet in England?" Wells abandoned his PhD and became a professional musician. He played in the quintet of pianist Lionel Grigson, who had a regular weekly gig at The Troubadour coffee house in Old Brompton Road,The Daryl Runswick Quartet 1973. with such musicians as Chris Bateson (trumpet), Pete Burden or Paul Zec on alto, and John Hart or David "Happy" Williams on bass.Spike Wells, "From 'Happy' Williams to Cedar Walton", 17 December 2018.
*1973: Mike Taylor Remembered (with Jon Hiseman, Barbara Thompson, Ian Carr, Henry Lowther, Norma Winstone, Ron Mathewson, Stan Sulzmann, Alan Branscombe and Chris Pyne, among others)

Mick Pyne (2 September 1940, in Thornton Dale – 23 May 1995, in London) was an English jazz pianist. His brother was jazz musician Chris Pyne.
